column9: This is a very moving drama which pretends to be true but is only partially true. The film aims to re-create a mythical world, if something which did not exist could be said to be re-created. The exteriors were shot in the beautiful Wicklow Hills of Ireland, which bear no resemblance to Hampshire in England. Anyone who has been to Jane Austen's village of Chawton knows that her house (which is open to the public) did not abut a huge ancient forest, and that there were no magnificent and grand sweeping views of hills and coombes there. In the film, we see Jane living in a rectory which is isolated in the depths of the country, whereas the real Jane would not have been able to avoid bumping into all her neighbours the minute she stepped from her door. The real Jane's life was thus claustrophobic, whereas in the film she seems to live on the verge of being wild and free, when she is not slopping the hogs (which it is doubtful she ever did herself). It was audacious to cast a girl from Brooklyn as Jane Austen, though the actress who calls herself Anne Hathaway (!) clearly has Anglophile leanings, and does a very good job. She manages to speak English, which shows remarkable talent and, frankly, is amazing. James McAvoy as Mr. Lefroy is very energetic and impassioned, and does a very good job. He looks very like my friend Charlie Anderson, though not as good looking. I think Maggie Smith over-acts in this film, or am I imagining it? Julie Walters, a great favourite of mine, seems barely there, and was probably miscast. James Cromwell is very effective indeed as the father. What one thinks of this film depends entirely on whether one wants historical truth or historical myth. Here we have more myth than truth. It seems hopeless ever to expect a historical film to be accurate, as the manufacturing of myths is the basic business of the film industry, where truth is a rare and despised commodity. The theatre has been described generically as 'lies like truth'. One might describe the cinema as 'lies like lies'. In film, illusion is everything. There is no use looking for reality on any screen, as it is not there. But then, there is this problem about real life as well: since most people live their lives based upon fantasies which have little connection with reality (false or demented notions, ludicrous ideas, crazy beliefs), and their actions are largely dictated by subconscious urges which they do not understand and of which they rarely even have the slightest conscious comprehension, what is reality, after all? If life is a dream, what is film? A double-dream? A dream thrown back in our faces? Films are imaginary, but how real are most people's actual lives? And this brings us to the question: how real was Jane Austen's life? She lived cooped up in an oppressive, ritualised, highly conventional society which would not allow her to have freedom of movement or behaviour, and she fled into the realms of the imagination. What is real about that? I suspect that Jane Austen, if she is out there somewhere and has seen the movie at The Aethre (a possible name for that great cinema in the sky) must have had a hearty laugh and must still be giggling. A girl from Brooklyn with a Shakespearian name swooning over James McAvoy in the Wicklow Hills? Why not? In fiction, anything goes, even attempts at pastiche biography. If it makes you laugh and cry, it must be OK. Let's say this film is a lovely experience and leave it at that.

column9:
This movie is fascinating in the sense that it takes the characters from the author's novels and writes them back into an imagined (largely) story of herself. This is not difficult because Jane Austen wrote about the world she lived in, accentuating the plight of the financially dependent woman. The closest resemblance is to "Pride and Prejudice", except that while Jane Austen found true liberation in becoming truly financially independent as a popular author, Lizzie Bennet's liberation is only partial, in finding happiness with a "good" husband. Comparison with the latest version of "Pride and Prejudice" (2005) easily identifies almost identical characters: Donald Sutherland and James Cromwell playing the understanding and supportive father, Judi Dench and Maggie Smith playing the icy, autocratic upper class woman. Tom Lefroy, unfortunately, is not Mr Darcy as in Jane Austen's own story, not only the woman, but also the man, is financially dependent.

An interesting theme that we find only in "Becoming Jane" but not Jane's novels is: how does a woman author with so little experience (in life, and some of its ingredients such as sex) go about writing a novel that is convincing? Mrs Radcliffe, a successful author that Jane visited, suggests using a lot of imagination. Tom Lefroy has more a practical advice: go and acquire the actual experience. As this is easier said than done, Jane resorts to the next best thing: reading novels written by people who purportedly have experience, for example, "Tom Jones".

"Becoming Jane" can be viewed as one of the steps for Ann Hathaway to becoming a major actress to be reckoned with. From the rodeo girl turned frustrated wife in "Brokeback Mountain" (where she has shown good potentials) she moved along to a major role in "The Devil wears Prada" in which she has to play against both formidable Meryl Streep and show-stealing Emily Blunt. Against those two, is it very difficult to hold your own and she was generally considered to have made passing grade. With "Becoming Jane" finally comes her chance and she comes through. Rarely seen on screen is such freshness and sincerity, bringing life to an imagined Jane Austen. Here she also has a partner who complements rather than rivals her. James McAvoy, who played so well against award winning Forest Whitaker in "The last king of Scotland" (2006), has fantastic chemistry with Hathaway, bringing out the best in her.

My last comment is quite inconsequential but I can't resist making it. It is one of the opening shots, showing Jane Austen's parents (James Cromwell and Julie Walters) in bed, just waking up in the morning. In the course of a conversation about perfection, Mrs Austen says, "I've shared your bed for 32 years and perfection I have not encountered". Without missing a beat, Rev Austen says "Yet". The next thing we see is the gentleman ducking his head under the blanket, moving towards the lower portion of the lady's abdomen, and then an expression of pleasure on her face. The movie makers surely know how to make the audience pay attention right from the beginning of the movie.

Becoming Jane is a fiction. What historical drama is not? I'm always fascinated by the range of response to artistic license when exercised by others. Perhaps it helps sometimes to go in with less knowledge and fewer expectations so that the movie can be viewed on its own merits.

As a movie period piece, Becoming Jane has a lot to recommend it. The cinematography had some brilliant moments. The dialog is possessed of some truly humorous and acerbic irony. The actors work as an ensemble and individually. Anne Hathaway is unquestionably lovely and captivating. Jennifer Ehle is still my favorite from the various Austen-style movies, but Hathaway charms me consistently.

And Becoming Jane has a dark turn that presents the very irony admired by so many in Jane Austen's novels. I confess to liking sweet and romantic movies, but a bit of pathos can work wonders. Other personal favorites are An Ideal Husband, The Whole Wide World and The Last of the Mohicans. Becoming Jane is more cerebral than Michael Mann's Mohicans and less dark than Tarzan's author. The dialog is not as witty as Oscar Wilde, but Jane has its moments. Each of these offer interesting ties back to literary favorites. Jane worked on every level for me and is not a poor cousin to these fine movies.

There was even some fun or sport in translating the depicted life experience into the implied inspiration. As I know Jane Austen more from the recent movies than from the original books the game is not that different from finding an homage in other movies.

I took my wife and college-age daughter. We all gave it a 5-star (out of 5) ranking and enjoyed an evening of discussing what we liked. Bottom line we found an engaging story where we cared about the characters and could empathize with both their triumphs and tragedies. Becoming Jane is a visual treat with some depth in its own right. The immersive theater experience makes it easier for me to suspend disbelief or the inner skeptic. Perhaps this is a movie that requires that suspension of disbelief. If you know too much about Jane Austen the accumulation of fictions appears too much to bear for many, as evidenced by other reviews. If you are simply inclined to romantic dramas, you may react as I did. I fell in love and will watch this one again, probably several times.

"Becoming Jane (2007)" was directed by Julian Jarrold. It stars Anne Hathaway as Jane Austen, and James McAvoy as Tom Lefroy, a young Irish law student with whom she falls in love.

Most viewers will know that Jane Austen wrote novels that are full of romance and, ultimately, marriage. The film explores the possibility that her novels depict actual events in her life, and events that she wished had been in her life.

The acting is excellent, as is true in so many British period pieces. The countryside footage (mostly filmed in Ireland) is wonderful, and we get many scenes of elegant dances as well as the requisite rural folk, their customs, and their animals.

Julie Walters is excellent as Jane's mother, as is James Cromwell as her father. Maggie Smith, one of the world's greatest actors, is perfect as the very rich and very selfish Lady Gresham.

The restricted role in society occupied by genteel women is rarely mentioned, but obvious throughout. Even the most admirable woman could hope for little more than a "good" marriage. Also ignored is the fact that, although Mrs. Austen complains about having to dig her own potatoes, these women do not really work. Surrounding them are faceless, nameless people who are lower in the social pyramid. Although the Austens recoil from the prospect of drudgery, drudgery is the lot in life of the vast majority of women and men around them.

This is a fine movie and definitely worth seeking out. The only problem I could find with it is that Jane Austen is too perfect, and that Anne Hathaway is too beautiful. In the movie, Jane is a superwoman--compassionate, loving, charitable, witty, brilliant, athletic, and attractive. She certainly must have been brilliant, but it's doubtful whether any human could have all the other characteristics as well.

The camera loves Anne Hathaway, and director Jarrold must love her too. Jarrold places Jane in virtually every scene, shot from virtually every angle, wearing virtually every possible flattering costume. The camera lavishes all its attention on her, and the other characters in the film fade away. Still, it's a movie about Jane Austen, and Ms. Hathaway looks wonderful in late 18th-Century costumes. Who can blame Julian Jarrold for his choices?

I wasn't entirely sure what to expect from this film, if only because although I know and love many of Jane Austen's books, I must confess I know very little about the lady herself.

The film stunned me and I enjoyed every second of it, even if it did feel slightly long. Whilst the film does not focus so much on Jane's writing, it does speculate about her life and the 'romance' between her and Thomas Lefroy. Although I discovered that the film is not historically accurate, I would still recommend this to anyone who enjoys a love story. In fact, due to the inaccuracies of the story, I would even go as far to suggest to just forget it's about Jane Austen and watch it as any other film! I left the cinema feeling thoroughly miserable! But only because the film did its work so well, and I found it refreshing to watch a love story that ends a little more realistically (the girl does not always get her man).

Overall I enjoyed the acting of all the cast, but I must make a special point to express how fantastic James McAvoy was! His portrayal of Thomas Lefroy was absolutely heart stopping; the only downside was that he was playing an Irishman, but did not have an Irish accent. This is the first film I have seen Anne Hathaway in, I felt that she could have perhaps have made her character Jane be a bit stronger, but she did the whole 'smitten' part superbly.

This is not my normal type of film, and I rarely enjoy romance dramas, but I'm afraid I turned into a proper girl on this occasion and was completely touched by the story. I think the main thing to bear in mind is that if you don't concentrate too much on what the story is supposed to be about, it's a cracking film. If you want it to give a credible tale of Jane Austen and her life, you may not be so lucky.

Again, to enjoy this movie, you have to believe in true love and not mind a slow-moving movie that shows a lot of moping.

I recommend this for moms and fans of Jane Austen. To everyone else, I recommend you at least rent it so you get a piece of history while enjoying a beautiful movie.

column9: Really marvelous, and somewhat reminiscent of Miss Potter. I went into the theater with what I would call average expectations; they were quickly exceeded. I thought this film was casted very well, the costumes were wonderfully authentic as was the dialogue, the soundtrack was lovely, and the locations were fantastic. I found the plot to be clever and captivating, and in addition, the growth and emotions the characters display seems quite genuine. In general, I rarely admit that I become entirely engrossed in a film, smirking at comical remarks and particularly romantic scenes; likewise, I found myself feeling rather curious and rebellious, often mirroring the emotions that Jane feels. Truly, I felt as though I had fallen into Miss Austen's Hampshire forest and become a part of the story. The cast was superb, all of the characters brought passion and sparked life in a setting that some would describe as stuffy and dull. Although, Hathway is an American, I completely felt as though she more than lived up to the role's high demands (her accent being rather passable); she gives the character of Jane a spirit and life that is easily identified with by young women in audiences. But of course, how could I forget the delightful, and attractive, Tom Lefroy. James McAvoy melts into this role so smoothly and effortlessly, and honestly, who could deny his stellar looks and charm? All memory of him as a faun in the Chronicals of Narnia being pushed from thought, he has morphed into a charming British Dandy that is sure to flutter the hearts of adolescent girls as well as the rest of the general female population that is not blind. The chemistry between Hathaway and McAvoy does much more than bubble and simmer, it boils. In addition, Maggie Smith is a familiar face that once again works its magic (no pun intended with Harry Potter), Julie Walters (who also plays Mrs. Weaseley in Harry Potter) was simply fabulous, as was James Cromwell. The movie was brilliant, beautiful, witty, romantic, artistic, and real. Most of all real, which I believe Miss Austen would have greatly approved of: "My characters shall have, after a little trouble, all that they desire." --Miss Austen.

"A woman especially if she has the misfortune of knowing anything, should conceal it as well as she can." Jane Austen

Fortunately, Anne Hathaway as Jane Austen in Becoming Jane doesn't conceal her character's intelligence by her bearing and occasional quips, which are barbed missiles most of us supposed "intellectuals" would have been wise to avoid 200 years ago. Before her famous period, Jane Austen met a young Irishman, Tom Lefroy, and this rendition does the docudrama approach to imagine what happened between them.

With the exception of an exchange about Fielding's Tom Jones, most of the action in this pleasant biopic is probably fiction but based on Jane's character as it is filtered through Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility, for instance. That a young girl of limited circumstances, such as a parson's daughter, should marry well is axiomatic in rigid early 19thÂcentury England. That a roguish young barrister who relies on a rich uncle to live a comfortable life should look for a wife among the wealthy is also de rigueur.

By falling in love, after the caustic interchanges that usually lead to affection in film and literature, Jane and Tom swiftly become as characters out of an Austen romance. Where the film disappoints me is those moments, such as with the Lady Gresham (Maggie Smith), where Jane backs away from a smart retort out of deference, undoubtedly proper activity at that time but unsatisfying dramatically since we have at the table one of the greatest communicators in the English language.

When she does argue with Tom's uncle, Judge Langlois (Ian Richardson), about the meaning of irony, like the film critic Ego's candid analysis of his trade in Ratatouille, the "irony" argument opens up new thinking about an old topic, just what you'd expect from a brilliant author. I need more of that and less realistic convention. A docudrama should try hard to reveal the genius of its subject.

But the story rightly turns on marriage and the conventions that could derail even a transcendent author. As Mrs. Austen reminds us, "Affection is desirable. Money is absolutely indispensable!" So Jane's life is determined by rigid class proprieties while her novels will force them to begin their downward slide for the next 200 years. Such is the irony of life.

Another movie I missed in the theatre but caught up with Â and thoroughly enjoyed - on a TransAtlantic flight. Becoming Jane is a pleasant, if not exactly groundbreaking movie, which explores the possibility that Jane Austen (and I have to put my cards on the table here and admit I'm a big Austen fan) took her artistic inspiration from a thwarted and doomed love affair in her youth. The best comparison I can give is with Shakespeare in Love.

Of course it is all wild speculation. Quite possibly Jane Austen was just an incredibly astute reader of other people's emotions and didn't necessarily need to have experienced a broken heart herself to be able to write about it. But she certainly understood the economic and social pressures of the time which often dictated people's choice of marriage partner. Love was an afterthought, and if you found it, you were lucky.

Anne Hathaway and James McAvoy give engaging performances, although I must admit I thought Ms Hathaway was perhaps a touch too beautiful for the role. However I can't fault her as an actress. I just have a feeling at the back of my mind (possibly quite unfounded) that had Jane Austen been as beautiful as Anne Hathaway, she would not have stayed unmarried, and, being saddled from then on by pregnancy and child-rearing, would probably not have given us those literary masterpieces.

James McAvoy seems to be in everything I watch at the moment, from Starter for Ten to Last King of Scotland to Atonement to Â..and on and on. Some of those movies I've enjoyed more than others, although on the whole I have enjoyed McAvoy's performances in them. He seems to have come from nowhere, but looking on his IMDb profile I see that in fact he has been around for well over 10 years, working solidly. Much as I like him, I think he needs to avoid becoming over exposed too quickly, or we will tire of him. Anne Hathaway seems to be picking her roles carefully, and I think she too will be around for a long time.

In part due to the mediocre IMDb rating I had low expectations for this picture. I expected a movie picture fantasy about Jane Austen. What I got was an entertaining film that managed to be true to her work. The story has an actual historical basis and vividly depicts the harsh environment out of which Austen's work came. All of her fans, at least one time, when facing injustice, adversity, personal errors in judgment, or difficult decisions, have asked themselves what would Jane Austen have done? Her characters rely on reason and, well, character to get them through life's slings and arrows. Her work is keenly concerned with the consequences of actions. She counsels doing the right thing in spite of immediate adverse consequences because the alternatives lead to worse consequences. Austen instructs in the efficacy of grasping the nettle. All of this is captured in the film. I have a few quibbles, but given the film's accomplishment at getting Austen right, they are not worth mentioning.

Set in England around 1795, this film depicts a romance in the early life of Jane Austen. This particular summer romance may have been pivotal in Jane Austen's career as a novelist. The film is very well-done by the BBC and brings its characters and their times vibrantly to life on the screen. The plot moves forward at a nice pace. At no time did my interest sag. There are no car-chases, explosions, or special effects, so already it's way ahead of most of today's films. Of course, that also classifies BECOMING JANE as a Chick Flick. So, if you like romances -- and especially one based on historical fact -- I recommend you see BECOMING JANE.
